meaningMnemonic: This is an intransitive version of 擦る, so it means <vocabulary>to be rubbed</vocabulary>. It often implies damage, in which case it can mean <vocabulary>to be grazed</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>to be scraped</vocabulary>, like when your knee gets grazed against a rough wall.
readingMnemonic:
You really don’t want your knee <vocabulary>to be grazed</vocabulary>. If it happens, you are gonna <reading>sue</reading> (す). But the <reading>cos</reading>t (こす) of suing is pretty high, so be careful not to get grazed in the first place!

Depending on which reading you use, the nuance changes slightly. For example, すれる is the usual choice when you’re talking about your grazed knees or worn out jeans. For other uses, they are often interchangeable.
